contentrichtext.text: '''George Grande''' (pronounced like the English word "grand") is an [[United States|American]] [[sportscaster]] who hosted the first broadcast of ''[[SportsCenter]]'' on [[ESPN]] in 1979.<ref>http://frontrow.espn.go.com/tag/george-grande/</ref> ==Early life and career== He graduated from the [[University of Southern California]] in 1969, where he played baseball for four years and was a member of the Trojans' team that won the [[1968 College World Series]]. While at USC, he played with 14 future Major Leaguers, including Hall of Famer [[Tom Seaver]] and slugger [[Dave Kingman]].<ref name="mlb">http://cincinnati.reds.mlb.com/team/broadcasters.jsp?c_id=cin</ref> He began his broadcasting career as a USC student in 1967 as the sports director and news director of the university's radio station, [[KUSC]]-FM, followed by radio stints at: [[KNX (AM)|KNX]] in [[Los Angeles]]; WERI in [[Westerly, Rhode Island]]; and WNHC in [[New Haven, Connecticut]]. He completed his radio broadcast career by handling the [[Boston Red Sox]] pre-game and post-game shows on [[WUFC (AM)|WMEX]]. Prior to joining [[ESPN]], Grande served as a sportscaster on TV station [[WTNH]] in New Haven.<ref name="mlb" /> ==ESPN== Grande was the second person to be seen on ESPN when it launched on September 7, 1979, following an introduction to the network by [[Lee Leonard]].<ref>http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vKyRslWcbho</ref> In the early years of the network, he served as host of the ''Inside Baseball'' weekly magazine program that evolved into the current ''[[Baseball Tonight]]'' program on [[ESPN]]. ==Major League Baseball play-by-play== Grande was a TV [[play-by-play]] announcer for [[Major League Baseball]]'s [[New York Yankees]] in [[1989 New York Yankees season|1989]] and [[1990 New York Yankees season|1990]], for the [[St. Louis Cardinals]] in [[1991 St. Louis Cardinals season|1991]] and [[1992 St. Louis Cardinals season|1992]]. He joined the [[Cincinnati Reds]] TV broadcast team and was its lead broadcaster from [[1993 Cincinnati Reds season|1993]] to [[2009 Cincinnati Reds season|2009]] for [[Fox Sports Ohio]].<ref>[http://msn.foxsports.com/id/4568191 FSN Ohio On-Air Talent]</ref> He teamed with former player [[Chris Welsh]] to form the longest-running TV broadcasting partnership in team history. On October 4, 2009, Grande announced that he would step down after 17 seasons with the Reds, stating that he wanted to spend more time with his family.<ref name="Sheldon">{{cite news|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20091004&content_id=7315620&vkey=news_mlb&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb|title=Grande exit for play-by-play veteran|last=Sheldon|first=Mark|date=2009-10-04|publisher=MLB.com|accessdate=2009-10-04}}</ref> However, he has since returned for a small number of games each season through 2013.<ref name="mlb" /> Grande also served as [[master of ceremonies]] for the [[National Baseball Hall of Fame]]'s annual inductions for 31 years, from 1980 to 2010.<ref name="mlb" /> Grande is on the board of directors for [[USA Baseball]].<ref>http://web.usabaseball.com/about/board.jsp</ref> == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://cincinnati.reds.mlb.com/NASApp/mlb/team/broadcasters.jsp?c_id=cin reds.com - Broadcasters] {{sportscenter}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Grande, George | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Grande, George}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American television sports announcers]] [[Category:Cincinnati Reds broadcasters]] [[Category:Major League Baseball announcers]] [[Category:New York Yankees broadcasters]] [[Category:St. Louis Cardinals broadcasters]] [[Category:USC Trojans baseball players]]
